docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme classifications, kinetics, thermodynamic principles.

  7. Enzyme Regulation

    • Enzyme inhibition, covalent modifications, ligand-protein interactions.

  8. Carbohydrates

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  9. Nucleic Acids

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

docs.title: Topic 1: The Molecular Design of Life
docs.text: Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

docs.title: Sections
docs.text:
• Which Macromolecule Does This Chemical Structure Represent?

  • Which of the Chemical Formula is Hydrophobic (HTML)?

  • Which of the Chemical Formula is Hydrophobic (MD)?

docs.title: Galactobiose Identification Question
docs.text:
Guide to Identifying the Chemical Structures of Macromolecules Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • Should have about the same number of oxygens as carbons.
  • Look for hydroxyl groups (–OH) attached to the carbon atoms.
  • Carbonyl groups (C=O) are often present as well.
  • Look for the base unit of CH2O.
  • Larger carbohydrates will form hexagon or pentagon ring-like structures.

docs.title: Question
docs.text: Which one of the four main types of macromolecules is represented by the chemical structure of galactobiose shown above?

docs.title: Answers:
docs.text:
• A. Carbohydrates (monosaccharides) - Correct
  • B. Lipids (fatty acids) - Incorrect
  • C. Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides) - Incorrect
  • D. Nucleic acids (nucleobases) - Incorrect

docs.title: Multiple Choice Question
docs.text:
Based on only their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely a lipid?

C11H15N5O11 C14H17N8O7P C14H17N8O8P C10H13O4N5 C40H58O3 Check

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH scales, buffering systems.

docs.title: Optimal Buffering Range
docs.text:
Pyrophosphoric acid and its conjugate base, pyrophosphate, is abbreviated PPi and is formed by cells from the hydrolysis of ATP into AMP.Pyrophosphoric acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 0.91, 2.10, 6.70, and 9.32.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Pyrophosphoric acid?

  • A. pH 0.4
  • B. pH 1.4
  • C. pH 2.3
  • D. pH 4.3
  • E. pH 8.4
Check Answer

docs.title: pKa Buffer State Questions
docs.text:
Oxalic acid and its conjugate base, oxalate, is found in many plants and vegetables and is a product of metabolic processes.Oxalic acid is diprotic with pKa values of 1.27 and 4.28.Oxalic acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 2.0?

  • A. (COOH)2
  • B. (HOOC)COO-
  • C. (COO)22-
Check Answer

Citric acid and its conjugate base, citrate, is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Citric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 3.13, 4.76, and 6.39.Citric acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 1.5?

  • A. HOC3H4(COOH)3
  • B. HOC3H4(COOH)2(COO)-
  • C. HOC3H4(COOH)(COO)22-
  • D. HOC3H4(COO)33-
Check Answer

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 8.0?

  • A. C10H12N2O84-
  • B. C10H13N2O83-
  • C. C10H14N2O82-
  • D. C10H15N2O8-
  • E. C10H16N2O8
Check Answer
